title: First Lady of China provides anti-epidemic materials to Côte d'Ivoire in August 2020
description: On August 25, 2020, the Chinese Ambassador to Côte d'Ivoire, Wan Li, on behalf of Mrs. Peng Liyuan, the First Lady of the People's Republic of China, provided a batch of medical equipment to Mrs. Dominique Ouattara, the First Lady of the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire. The donated materials included 18,000 single use surgical masks and 120 temperature guns. These materials will be distributed to women, children, and adolescents in Côte d'Ivoire as part of the country’s COVID-19 response effort. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony took place for this donation in the meeting room of the General Secretariat of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Côte d'Ivoire. China’s Ambassador to  Côte d'Ivoire, Wan Li, the First Lady of Côte d'Ivoire, Dominique Ouattara, the Deputy Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the Director of the Asia-Pacific Department attended the ceremony. A handover certificate was signed at the ceremony.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

The donated materials included 18,000 single use surgical masks and 120 temperature guns. These materials will be distributed to women, children, and adolescents in Cte d'Ivoire as part of the countrys COVID-19 response effort. The monetary value of this donation is unknown. A handover ceremony took place for this donation in the meeting room of the General Secretariat of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Cte d'Ivoire. Chinas Ambassador to Cte d'Ivoire, Wan Li, the First Lady of Cte d'Ivoire, Dominique Ouattara, the Deputy Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the Director of the Asia-Pacific Department attended the ceremony. A handover certificate was signed at the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for public health purposes, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of 18,000 surgical masks and 120 temperature guns for COVID-19 response, targeted at women, children, and adolescents

title: Chinese Embassy in Romania donates 350 million Romanian lei to Chamber of Deputies for office equipment
description: On January 22, 2004, the donation protocol was signed for the donation of 350 million leu from the Chinese Embassy to the Romanian Parliament. The aid will be used to purchase office equipment and computers for the Chamber of Deputies. The protocol was signed in the presence of the Chamber of Deputies' Speaker Valer Dorneanu, the Chinese Embassy's chargee d'affaires Wang Tieshan, and the Chamber's secretary-general Mihai Ungheanu.  On June 14, 2004, the Romanian Minister of Economy and Trade, Dan Ioan Popescu, and the Chinese Minister of Trade, Bo Xilai, signed a paper confirming the donation had been received.
combined_text: # Sector GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY # Title Chinese Embassy in Romania donates 350 million Romanian lei to Chamber of Deputies for office equipment # Description On January 22, 2004, the donation protocol was signed for the donation of 350 million leu from the Chinese Embassy to the Romanian Parliament. The aid will be used to purchase office equipment and computers for the Chamber of Deputies. The protocol was signed in the presence of the Chamber of Deputies' Speaker Valer Dorneanu, the Chinese Embassy's chargee d'affaires Wang Tieshan, and the Chamber's secretary-general Mihai Ungheanu. On June 14, 2004, the Romanian Minister of Economy and Trade, Dan Ioan Popescu, and the Chinese Minister of Trade, a Chinese official, signed a paper confirming the donation had been received.
justification: Project involves donation for office equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for office equipment and computers, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government provides $4 million grant for Phase 1 of Egyptian Remote Education Project (Linked to Project ID#500 and ID#65829)
description: In 2002, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided a $4 million grant to the Government of Egypt for Phase 1 of the Egyptian Remote Education Project (captured in Project ID#543). Then, on December 6, 2004, Egypt's Minister of State for International Cooperation, Fayza Abul Nagaa, and China's Minister of Commerce, Bo Xilai, signed an RMB 30,000,000 (approximately $4.5 million) grant agreement for Phase 2 of the Egyptian Remote Education Project (captured in Project ID#500).  Then, on October 27, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Egypt signed an exchange of letters, committing RMB 79 million ($11.5 million) of grant funding for Phase 3 of the Egyptian Remote Education Project (captured in Project ID#65829).   Egyptian Presidential Order No. (2019) ratified the exchange of letters into Egyptian law on June 24, 2019. The grant proceeds for Phase 3 were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on December 23, 2014.  The purpose of the Egyptian Remote Education Project was to establish a distance learning network for Egypt's Ministry of Education. The network was designed to support basic educational courses, lectures, and teacher training activities.   The project was implemented in three phases. Phase 1 involved the establishment of 33 distance learning terminals in 27 Egyptian governorates. It also sought to connect these terminals to a training center in ‘Mubarak Education City’ in the city of ‘6th of October’ (Arabic: السادس من أكتوبر‎) within Giza governorate. Each terminal was equipped with video, audio, and remote white board devices. Phase 2 involved an expansion of the network from 33 terminals to 143 terminals in 27 Egyptian governorates. The purpose of Phase 3 is to expand, upgrade, and  transform the measures and technologies already put in place during Phase 1 and 2. It involves an expansion of the network from 143 terminals to 200 terminals (through the installation of audio-visual technologies in 57 additional Egyptian schools). Its ultimate aim is to address a lack of teachers in some schools by connecting students and teachers through audio-visual technologies. Phase 1 project design work began in late 2001. MOFCOM then issued a Phase 1 implementation contract to ZTE Corporation in August 2002.    Phase 1 was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on March 18, 2003.  On May 21, 2006, the Government of Egypt’s General Authority For Educational Buildings and China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation (CITCC) signed a Phase 2 implementation contract. Phase 2 commenced on January 31, 2007 and reached completion on June 30, 2007. Then, on January 19, 2016, the Egyptian Ministry of Education and ZTE Corporation signed a cooperation agreement related to Phase 3.  As of early 2021, Phase 3 had not yet entered implementation.
staff_comments: 1. Egypt’s Ministry of International Cooperation identifies an RMB 79 million grant for the Implementation of Remote Education System Upgrade 'Phases 1 and 2' and Extension 'Phase 3' Project. It is unclear if this grant commitment is separate from and additional to the grant commitments captured via Project ID#500 and Project ID#543. This issue warrants further investigation.  See  https://moic.gov.eg/project/84 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/lm2ar2kowlrk7ox/Implementation%20of%20Remote%20Education%20System%20Upgrade%20%22Phases%201%20and%202%22%20and%20Extension%20%22Phase%203%22.pdf?dl=02. This project is also known as Phase 1 of the China-Aided Distance Education Project in Egypt. The Chinese project title is 中国援埃远程教育项目. The Arabic project title is المرحلة الثانية من مشرالتعليم عن بعد الذي

Then, on December 6, 2004, Egypt's Minister of State for International Cooperation, Fayza Abul Nagaa, and China's Minister of Commerce, a Chinese official, signed an RMB 30,000,000 (approximately $4.5 million) grant agreement for Phase 2 of the Egyptian Remote Education Project (captured in Project ID#500). Then, on October 27, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Egypt signed an exchange of letters, committing RMB 79 million ($11.5 million) of grant funding for Phase 3 of the Egyptian Remote Education Project (captured in Project ID#65829). title: Chinese government donates anti-epidemic materials to the National Women's Union of Djibouti in August 2020
description: On August 5, 2020, the Chinese government donated anti-epidemic materials to the National Women’s Union of Djibouti. The wife of President Xi Jinping, Peng Liyuan, donated these materials on behalf of the Chinese government. These materials will be used for COVID-19 response and prevention efforts in Djibouti. The specific type, amount, and monetary value of this donation are unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. At the ceremony, China’s Ambassador to Djibouti, Zhuo Ruisheng, met with the National Women's Union of Djibouti Vice Chairman and handed over the materials. The Minister of Women and Family, representatives from the National Assembly, and the Minister of Health also attended the ceremony. Ambassador Zhuo and Vice Chairman Hasna signed the handover certificate on behalf of China and Djibouti respectively.
combined_text: # Sector HEALTH # Title Chinese government donates anti-epidemic materials to the National Women's Union of Djibouti in August 2020 # Description On August 5, 2020, the Chinese government donated anti-epidemic materials to the National Womens Union of Djibouti. The wife of President Xi Jinping, a Chinese official, donated these materials on behalf of the Chinese government. These materials will be used for COVID-19 response and prevention efforts in Djibouti. The specific type, amount, and monetary value of this donation are unknown. A handover ceremony was held for this donation. At the ceremony, Chinas Ambassador to Djibouti, Zhuo Ruisheng, met with the National Women's Union of Djibouti Vice Chairman and handed over the materials. The Minister of Women and Family, representatives from the National Assembly, and the Minister of Health also attended the ceremony. Ambassador Zhuo and Vice Chairman Hasna signed the handover certificate on behalf of China and Djibouti respectively.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support and social development through COVID-19 response materials
evidence: Donation of anti-epidemic materials for COVID-19 response and prevention, no direct energy or environmental impact

title: Chinese First Lady donates anti-epidemic supplies to Ethiopia in August 2020
description: On August 14, 2020, donations by Peng Liyuan, the First Lady of China, arrived in Ethiopia to help the country’s effort to curb the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic. The donations consisted of 18,000 surgical masks and 120 infrared thermometers. The First Lady's office announced the donation on August 11, 2020. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

The donations consisted of 18,000 surgical masks and 120 infrared thermometers. The First Lady's office announced the donation on August 11, 2020. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a humanitarian donation of medical supplies unrelated to energy or environmental impact
evidence: Donation of surgical masks and infrared thermometers for COVID-19 pandemic response

title: Chinese government donated medical supplies to the Gabonese Government for COVID-19 relief in August 2020
description: On August 3rd 2020, the Chinese Government donates medical supplies to the Gabonese Government via Gabon's Foreign Minister. The purpose of this donation is to help the women and children of Gabon fight against the epidemic and increase their welfare. The exact contents of the donation are unknown.  The Chinese government's donation was provided to its member countries through the African First Ladies' Federation for Development (OAFLAD) on the initiative of Professor Peng Liyuan, the wife of Chinese President Xi Jinping. The amount and value of this donation are not specified.

The purpose of this donation is to help the women and children of Gabon fight against the epidemic and increase their welfare. The exact contents of the donation are unknown. The Chinese government's donation was provided to its member countries through the African First Ladies' Federation for Development (OAFLAD) on the initiative of Professor a Chinese official, the wife of Chinese President Xi Jinping. The amount and value of this donation are not specified.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare and social welfare without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical supplies donation for COVID-19 relief, focus on women and children welfare

title: Chinese government donates anti-epidemic supplies to Kenya OAFLAD in July 2020
description: On July 22, 2020, the First Lady of China, Peng Liyuan, donated a batch of anti-epidemic supplies on behalf of the Chinese government to Kenya. The aid was organized by the Organization of African First Ladies for Development, or OAFLAD, which is turning its attention to aiding mothers and children in the battle against COVID-19. The donation was received in support of Kenyan first lady Margaret Kenyatta's Beyond Zero initiative at the organization's headquarters in Nairobi. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text: # Sector HEALTH # Title Chinese government donates anti-epidemic supplies to Kenya OAFLAD in July 2020 # Description On July 22, 2020, the First Lady of China, a Chinese official, donated a batch of anti-epidemic supplies on behalf of the Chinese government to Kenya. The aid was organized by the Organization of African First Ladies for Development, or OAFLAD, which is turning its attention to aiding mothers and children in the battle against COVID-19. The donation was received in support of Kenyan first lady Margaret Kenyatta's Beyond Zero initiative at the organization's headquarters in Nairobi. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for public health purposes without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic supplies donation, focus on public health and COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Government donates the third batch of anti-COVID-19 pandemic medical supplies to Liberia in July 2020
description: On July 13th, 2020, the Chargé d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy in Liberia, Xu Kun, handed over the anti-epidemic materials donated by China to Liberia. This donation included forehead thermometers, masks, and a batch of rice.  Professor Peng Liyuan donated the materials on behalf of the Chinese government to the office of the wife of the President of Liberia. Gaelle Mediem, Director of the Office of the First Lady of Lebanon, Sherdrick Jackson, Assistant Minister of Foreign Affairs of Lebanon, and Li Jiang, Economic and Commercial Counselor attended the ceremony.  This batch of materials is the third batch of anti-epidemic materials donated by the Chinese government to Liberia. It also supports Professor Peng Liyuan, wife of Chinese President Xi Jinping, in helping women, children, and adolescents in African countries, including Liberia, fight the pandemic. In addition to masks and forehead thermometers, the Chinese Embassy also donated a batch of rice. China will continue to firmly support Liberia's anti-pandemic development, implement the consensus reached by the two countries' leaders, and continuously advance the friendship between China and Liberia.

evidence: Donation of medical supplies and food for pandemic relief, focus on supporting women and children

title: Chinese government donates anti-epidemic materials to Libyan Ministry for Women and Social Development Affairs in July 2020
description: On July 17, 2020, a handover ceremony was held for the donation of anti-epidemic materials from the Chinese government to the Libyan government. The purpose of the donation was to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 in Libya, particularly among women, children, and teenagers. The Chinese Charge d'Affaires to Libya, Wang Qimin, and the Libyan Charge d'Affaires to Tunisia, Mohamed Bin Mustafa, signed the handover certificate in Tunis, Tunisia. The exact materials donated are unknown.   This project is part of a larger initiative by the Chinese First Lady, Peng Liyuan. The initiative involved providing COVID relief supplies for vulnerable women and children to 53 African countries at the behest of the Organization of African First Ladies for Development.

The Chinese Charge d'Affaires to Libya, Wang Qimin, and the Libyan Charge d'Affaires to Tunisia, Mohamed Bin Mustafa, signed the handover certificate in Tunis, Tunisia. The exact materials donated are unknown. This project is part of a larger initiative by the Chinese First Lady, a Chinese official. evidence: Donation of anti-epidemic materials, focus on vulnerable populations, part of broader social development initiative
